body: The base error there is the last one, with `"os_error":"Cannot assign requested address"`. It looks like the operating system is preventing you from binding port 50051. You'll have to figure out what ports your hosting provider allows you to bind. You may want to try using the standard HTTPS port 443, assuming that you are enabling TLS.

Thanks for the response -- OS is Ubuntu. It's allowing me to bind to
localhost:50051, and allowing me to start the server when I set my host to
localhost or a custom domain (if I add an entry in /etc/hosts mapping the
custom domain back to 127.0.0.1). Does this offer any help?

I think that when you bind to `localhost` (in any of the variations you described), you are binding to the loopback interface instead of a network interface that connects to the outside world. Doing so is mostly only useful in tests, or if you're using a network connection as a kind of ad-hoc inter-process communication channel.

In other words, I think your hosting provider is not allowing you to bind the **external** port 50051.

good point, I'll try binding to 0.0.0.0 and see if this works
